text: Watch: The Queen's Christmas Broadcast 2019. #QueensSpeech #QueensChristmasBroadcast #HappyChristmaspic.twitter.com/Q16XjeoFZJ
Members of The Royal Family accompanied Her Majesty at the Christmas Church service this morning.pic.twitter.com/JswKB6pHxW
The Queen attended the Christmas morning service today at St Mary Magdalene Church in Sandringham. Thank you to everyone who came to say hello – and Merry Christmas!pic.twitter.com/kjwyJtOvlU
Happy Birthday to HRH Princess Alexandra! Princess Alexandra, The Queen's cousin, was born on Christmas Day in 1936. #HappyBirthdayHRHpic.twitter.com/6Q4IUb1icm

Merry Christmas everyone! Today marks the 68th Queen’s Christmas speech and the last of the decade. You can watch the broadcast at 3pm GMT on TV, radio and here online @RoyalFamily. #ChristmasDay2019 One: The Queen 2010 - 2018, Two: 2019pic.twitter.com/LT6SOi1XUl

The puddings will become the centerpieces of next year's 'Together at Christmas' get togethers, hosted by the Royal British Legion. Find out more here: https://bit.ly/393D8bE pic.twitter.com/KbDkZ7NcSd

The Queen, The Prince of Wales, The Duke of Cambridge and Prince George came together to make Christmas puddings at Buckingham Palace as part of a Royal British Legion initiative. Watch this clip as Her Majesty and Their Royal Highnesses take part in the pudding stir.pic.twitter.com/i3Xx2DtxhR

You can hear the choir, which dates back to 1348, during regular services at the Chapel in Windsor – and all are welcome at the Christmas services. More here: https://bit.ly/398Tvna pic.twitter.com/MJw6aRE5cX

The Choir of St George’s Chapel sing “Bogoroditse Devo” [‘Rejoice, O virgin'] composed by Arvo Pärt (b. 1935) #ARoyalChristmas Filmed and produced by Martin Stanford. Video © The Dean & Canons of Windsor. Audio ℗ Hyperion Records Ltd, London.pic.twitter.com/QjhLqq6cfp

“By being willing to put past differences behind us and move forward together, we honour the freedom and democracy once won for us at so great a cost.” Watch The Queen's Christmas broadcast on TV, radio and online here @RoyalFamily tomorrow at 3pm GMT. (3/3)

“For the Seventy-Fifth Anniversary of that decisive battle, in a true spirit of reconciliation, those who had formerly been sworn enemies came together in friendly commemorations either side of the Channel, putting past differences behind them…” Her Majesty will say. (2/3)

Merry Christmas! This year The Queen's Speech was filmed in the Green Drawing Room at Windsor Castle. It will be broadcast on Christmas Day at 3pm GMT. This year marked the 75th Anniversary of D-Day & in the speech Her Majesty will reflect on the commemorations. (1/3)pic.twitter.com/Mcw1k6LU5I

A new Royal British Legion recipe was created for the launch, with The Royal Family uniquely adding poppy seeds to the mixture, in a nod to the charity’s iconic symbol of Remembrance.pic.twitter.com/BGlHbD5p3R

The Queen is Patron of the British Legion & the puddings will be the centerpieces of the charity’s Christmas get-togethers. The pudding making was led by a Legion care home chef Alex Cavaliere & attended by veterans - Colin Hughes, Liam Young, Lisa Evans and Barbara Hurman.pic.twitter.com/K67BtFEWnx

The Queen, The Prince of Wales, The Duke of Cambridge and Prince George, joined forces to prepare special Royal British Legion Christmas puddings at Buckingham Palace this week.pic.twitter.com/HQQ3Dc6n0y
Four generations of The Royal Family have come together to support The Royal British Legion's "Together at Christmas" initiative.pic.twitter.com/mLHWVsvfjW

Thank you and Merry Christmas to @The_SCOTS The Queen is Colonel-in-Chief of The Royal Regiment of Scotland and @CplCruachan_IV is their mascot.https://twitter.com/The_SCOTS/status/1208000894731730945 …
Congratulations to all of today’s Investiture recipients, who were honoured at Buckingham Palace by The Duke of Cambridge.https://twitter.com/KensingtonRoyal/status/1207666676407386113 …

Before either House can proceed to public business, The Queen officially opens Parliament by addressing both Houses in The Queen's Speech. The #QueensSpeech is drafted by the Government and outlines plans and future legislation for the year ahead.pic.twitter.com/cK8f0249ZK
Today’s #StateOpening was the 66th occasion that The Queen has opened Parliament.pic.twitter.com/BqTFdJvXtr

The State Opening brings together all three parts of Parliament: the House of Commons, the House of Lords and the Monarch. Learn more about The Queen and Government: https://bit.ly/2s5hdjw #QueensSpeechpic.twitter.com/DB0LSfyzlS
You can watch today’s events at the Palace of Westminster live on the Parliament YouTube channel now:http://bit.ly/31dZW3t https://bit.ly/2PA0mhV Viewers in the UK can also watch on @BBCOne
The Queen, accompanied by The Prince of Wales, departs Buckingham Palace for the Palace of Westminster ahead of the State Opening of Parliament.pic.twitter.com/yb1RErbaWJ – at Buckingham Palace

Her Majesty The Queen, accompanied by The Prince of Wales, will open a new session of Parliament this morning. Find out more here: http://bit.ly/1TnoIqC #QueensSpeech #StateOpeningpic.twitter.com/69MjjwtHqu
Read more on our website:https://bit.ly/2sI5t6t

The Poetry Medal Committee recommended Lorna Goodison as this year's recipient on the basis of her body of work. The committee is chaired by the Poet Laureate Simon Armitage, who received The Queen’s Gold Medal for Poetry for 2018.pic.twitter.com/B6jfyZ81Dh

Lorna said: “I am honoured and deeply grateful… Love and justice, hope and possibility, healing and redemption are the themes I've always turned to.” She will collect the medal from The Queen in an Audience at Buckingham Palace in 2020. pic.twitter.com/k6KV3D420R

Lorna Goodison has been announced as the recipient of Her Majesty’s 2019 Gold Medal for Poetry. The Gold Medal for Poetry, established by King George V in 1933, is awarded for excellence in poetry. Each year’s recipient is from the United Kingdom or a Commonwealth Realm.pic.twitter.com/9h81Ndkc4G
Good luck for Christmas Day!https://twitter.com/williams_mrsj/status/1206542272625618944 …
Congratulations to @benstokes38, @BBCSport Personality of the Year! The Princess Royal presented Ben with the award at #SPOTY19 in Aberdeen this evening.pic.twitter.com/j2Y5IY8L0m

“I’ve been Patron of @MNDScotland for 30 years & I know what a difference you’ve made to the understanding of motor neurone disease & your ability to fund research. For that we’re extremely grateful.” - The Princess Royal presents @DoddieWeir5 with the Helen Rollason Award. https://twitter.com/BBCSport/status/1206298396035825665 …

Planning for the broadcast begins months in advance, when The Queen decides on the themes she wishes to address. The broadcast has been and remains the Monarch’s own personal message to the nation and Commonwealth. Read the 1977 speech: https://bit.ly/2Pmzwd4 pic.twitter.com/pMEbQ1dPMb
These images are from 7th June 1977, Jubilee Day, when a special service of thanksgiving was held at St Paul's Cathedral.pic.twitter.com/DSCaau46pk

“I shall never forget the scene outside Buckingham Palace on Jubilee Day. The cheerful crowd was symbolic of the hundreds of thousands of people who greeted us wherever we went in this Jubilee Year...” - The Queen’s Christmas Broadcast, 1977 #ARoyalChristmaspic.twitter.com/fn0lexVZeM

Want to make your own ‘Cinnamon Stars’? The Royal pastry chefs at Buckingham Palace are excited to share their recipe with you! #ARoyalChristmas Visit our website for the detailed recipe and method: https://bit.ly/2PNAbmy pic.twitter.com/2Kp73AyTyb

The Duchess of Cornwall and children supported by @HelenAndDouglas and @RoaldDahlFund yesterday decorated the Christmas tree at @ClarenceHouse https://twitter.com/ClarenceHouse/status/1205158700463394817 …

The first Christmas Trees arrived in Britain in the late 18th century and became popular after an engraving of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert decorating a tree with their young family was published in 1848.pic.twitter.com/CyK3eT3w0J

The tree has been decorated in a Victorian fashion with velvet and gold, in celebration of the 200th anniversary of the births of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. #ARoyalChristmaspic.twitter.com/BVajFNyLRR
Over 20,000 twinkling lights are glistening across Windsor Castle This year, a magical 20-foot-high Nordmann Fir tree is on display in St George’s Hall.pic.twitter.com/VKWDR3Bh2Y
Royal Residences have been transformed for the festive season with the arrival of Christmas Trees, including this one at Buckingham Palace #ARoyalChristmaspic.twitter.com/sCx7VDYgML

The Countess of Wessex hold a number of military appointments. She is Royal Colonel of 5th Battalion The Rifles, Colonel-in-Chief of the Corps of Army Music and of Queen Alexandra’s Royal Army Nursing Corps.pic.twitter.com/1mPINU5cKA
The Royal Family has long supported The Armed Forces. His Majesty King George VI, watched the first Commissioning parade in July 1948.pic.twitter.com/3cQOQmVOdW
Her Royal Highness is joined at The Parade by His Majesty the Yang di – Pertuan Agong and Her Majesty Raja Permaisuri Agong of Malaysia.pic.twitter.com/JQjD93PtQ5
The Countess presents awards to Officers including Long Service and Good Conduct Medals and The Sword of Honour.pic.twitter.com/vWkrTFFnMz
The Countess inspects the Parade made up of 690 cadets including 71 women.pic.twitter.com/NuzsFNSw6s – at Royal Military Academy Sandhurst

The Sovereign’s Parade is a special day for Officer Cadets @RMASandhurst . Today 242 Officer Cadets are passing out, after completing 44 weeks of training.pic.twitter.com/DF2TXM0z9e – at Royal Military Academy Sandhurst
The Countess of Wessex is at The Royal Military Academy Sandhurst, representing The Queen at The Sovereign’s Parade.pic.twitter.com/jubEawe3Nz – at Royal Military Academy Sandhurst

Her Majesty was presented with each Ambassador’s Letters of Credence, to mark the beginning of their new diplomatic positions. The Queen also held an audience with Mr Yasumasa Nagamine, Ambassador from Japan, and his wife, Mrs Nagamine.pic.twitter.com/nN1568uBpy

Today at Buckingham Palace, The Queen held audiences with Ambassadors from Panama and Japan. Mrs Natalia Royo Ruiz de Hagerman, Ambassador from Panama, and her husband Mr Santiago Hagerman Arnus, were received by Her Majesty.pic.twitter.com/ssJjSHUyc0

His Majesty the Yang di-Pertuan Agong and Her Majesty Raja Permaisuri Agong of Malaysia are in the UK for a week-long visit. Tomorrow, The Countess of Wessex and The King and Queen of Malaysia will visit The Royal Military Academy of Sandhurst for The Sovereign Parade.pic.twitter.com/hRfOrjinM5
The Earl of Wessex welcomed The King and Queen of Malaysia at Buckingham Palace today, along with four of their children. They were greeted inside the Palace by The Queen.pic.twitter.com/BaJLxvvxLG
This work includes the hosting of State Visits and The Queen’s regular audiences with Ambassadors and High Commissioners. Find out more here: https://bit.ly/2shE1wi pic.twitter.com/d1nuB0BYwo
The reception, attended by members of the Diplomatic Corps based in London, supports the work of the Royal Family in representing the UK at home and abroad.pic.twitter.com/jGFXUcHQaH
Tonight The Queen and Members of The Royal Family welcomed the world's ambassadors to #BuckinghamPalace at the annual Diplomatic Reception.pic.twitter.com/uAejRH6qwb

As Patron of The Royal College of Emergency Medicine, The Princess Royal also visited the Paediatric Emergency Department at the hospital. The department is celebrating its fifth anniversary.pic.twitter.com/KJmDttuCrG
The Maternity Ward at @Medway_NHS_FT received the @MidwivesRCM Midwifery Service of the Year Award 2019 pic.twitter.com/VCAQSqDwZO

The Princess Royal met 11-hour-old Noah this afternoon whilst visiting Medway Maritime Hospital’s Maternity Ward. HRH is Patron of The Royal College of Midwives, @MidwivesRCM pic.twitter.com/zFcQjfAWtv
At the Village Hall, The Princess Royal meets @EnglishRural Housing Staff, Builders, Architects, Funders and Parish Councillors. Thank you Huxley for the lovely flowers.pic.twitter.com/eepVVwTYCa
Jessie and her sons showed The Princess Royal around their new home. The Goldfield homes have been created in partnership with the local community.pic.twitter.com/kE1eyZFFIJ

“A Patron not just in name, she absolutely believes in what English Rural are doing: providing affordable housing, in local communities, for local people.” - Alison is the Senior Development Manager for @EnglishRural pic.twitter.com/WmfTQxx1wi

The Princess Royal, Patron of @EnglishRural, officially opened a new affordable housing development this morning. Recently completed, the small development of four new homes at ‘Goldfield’ will provide two houses and two flats that will benefit local people in Kent.pic.twitter.com/POMoyVZoZ3
In September, The Duke visited @RNLI Salcombe in Devon to celebrate 150 years of lifesaving - meeting crew, volunteers and people from the local community.pic.twitter.com/01t6GHcrDz

During his time as President, The Duke has attended countless lifeboat namings & station openings, & met volunteers and fundraisers who work to save lives at sea. HRH has been presented with a vellum certificate bearing the signature of Her Majesty The Queen, Patron of @RNLI.pic.twitter.com/X36wrmA6Rt
The Duke took on the role in 1969, succeeding his mother, Princess Marina, Duchess of Kent.pic.twitter.com/mA1O3ClEXG
HRH The Duke of Kent is celebrating 50 years as President of the Royal National Lifeboat Institution ( @RNLI) pic.twitter.com/fXXZjgmbY4

The Queen holds Audiences throughout her working week, often with members of the diplomatic community. At the beginning of a new diplomatic role, High Commissioners and Ambassadors will have an Audience with The Queen shortly after taking up their new role.
Sir Iakoba Italeli and his wife Lady Italeli, were also received by The Queen. Sir Iakoba is stepping down in his position as Governor General of Tuvalu.pic.twitter.com/KAHoKbYePL
The Queen also met with Ms Catherine Colonna, Ambassador of France.pic.twitter.com/ufErZWFldU
Today Her Majesty received Mr Mohammad Jaafar Bakr Haidar Al-Sadr. Ambassador from the Republic of Iraq.pic.twitter.com/OdJHYJb1N2

The Royal Christmas broadcast has evolved into an important part of the Christmas Day celebrations for many in Britain and around the world. Watch The #QueensSpeech from 1957 in full here: https://bit.ly/38f5cbP pic.twitter.com/UlNR6GuBNc

Twenty-five years later, in 1957, The Queen broadcast the first televised Christmas message. The #QueensSpeech was delivered live from the Long Library at Sandringham, Norfolk.pic.twitter.com/T5hYz15bjC

#DYK the Christmas message was started by The Queen's grandfather, King George V in 1932? The text was written by poet and writer Rudyard Kipling and included the words: "I speak now from my home and from my heart to you all." #ARoyalChristmaspic.twitter.com/ClhowhXtYW

The Countess met six-year-old Elizabeth and her parents Liam and Sinead. Sinead's family are sharing their experiences and raising awareness of the impact of scarring. Elizabeth has been treated by Professor Naiem Moiemen, Director of the Centre for Conflict Wound Research.pic.twitter.com/U01Lbaz7uw

Her Royal Highness has been Patron of @scarfreeworld since 2002, and last November opened the Foundation’s Centre for Conflict Wound Research at Queen Elizabeth Hospital, Birmingham.pic.twitter.com/5YC5sWtwyL

The Countess of Wessex, as Patron of the Scar Free Foundation, hosted an afternoon tea at Buckingham Palace on Wednesday to mark the Foundation’s 20th anniversary. @scarfreeworld is focused on advancing medical research in the areas of wound healing, burns and cleft lips.pic.twitter.com/kSbClnkaBd

Queen Margrethe is joint Patron of the Anglo-Danish Society, alongside Her Majesty The Queen. They are pictured here together during the Danish State Visit to the UK in 2000.pic.twitter.com/5nbByBRseU
The Duchess of Gloucester joined Her Majesty Queen Margrethe II of Denmark at the anniversary event.pic.twitter.com/74P8IXsvKx

The programme provides financial support to Danish and British graduates pursuing further education. The Duchess met scholars who have been supported by the Society, and heard about their studies in music, immunology and neuroscience.pic.twitter.com/bs5em2IoVj

This week, The Duchess of Gloucester helped the Anglo-Danish Society celebrate 60 years of their charitable scholarship programme. The Duchess, who was born in Denmark, is the programme's "Protector".pic.twitter.com/aIdqMLXsgE

The Duke and Duchess of Gloucester attended the Advent Procession at St Paul’s Cathedral, London, this week. The Duchess is Patron of the Friends of St Paul's Cathedral, a role previously held by Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother.pic.twitter.com/6VXuCmcH1C

‘Not Forgotten’ Garden Parties and Christmas Parties have taken place at Buckingham Palace and St James’s Palace since 1921. Read more about yesterday’s @nfassociation event on our website: http://bit.ly/33SGkmv pic.twitter.com/StqqOfDCDp

Princess Mary became the first Patron of @nfassociation shortly after its creation in 1920. Since 2000, The Princess Royal has acted as Patron, and yesterday met many of the charity’s volunteers at The Christmas reception.https://twitter.com/nfassociation/status/1202539990347141120 …

The charity provides injured or sick veterans with a range of entertainment and activities throughout the year. Dale Mallin spoke with us about the impact @nfassociation has had on his life since being medically discharged from the Army.pic.twitter.com/lxJUVM1u6E

The Princess Royal attended the annual Christmas reception for ‘The Not Forgotten’ ex-servicemen and women at St James’s Palace yesterday @nfassociation supports over 10,000 vulnerable members of the Armed Forces each year.pic.twitter.com/UIpBZMlX18

The Prince of Wales presented Honours to deserving people at an Investiture held in Buckingham Palace today More on Investiture ceremonies here: http://bit.ly/2VQeN5r https://twitter.com/ClarenceHouse/status/1202602546612842496 …

‘1917’ tells the story of two British soldiers, who are tasked with delivering a message across enemy territory. The premiere was the charity’s 71st Royal Film Performance. The Queen also attended the 1978 premier of Close Encounters of the Third Kind.pic.twitter.com/fh3skpkIwz

The first Royal Film Performance took place at the Empire Cinema in Leicester Square in 1946, and was attended by King George VI, Queen Elizabeth, Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret. The Queen has attended on several occasions, including the 1962 film premier of West Side Story.pic.twitter.com/cTT1DTQl7M
The Prince of Wales is Patron of The British Film Institute and is an avid supporter of those working in the film and television industry.pic.twitter.com/688lT8BgTs

Last night The Prince of Wales and The Duchess of Cornwall, @ClarenceHouse, attended the premier of @1917FilmUK in support of @FilmTVCharity. The Film and TV Charity showcase major films, with proceeds from events providing financial support to people from the screen industries.pic.twitter.com/76YjUXwWKj

The Princess Royal previously visited Fishmongers’ Hall on Thursday 14th November when she attended a Committee of Wardens meeting and Court meeting. Support for those affected by terrorist attacks in the UK can be found here:http://bit.ly/34PZT07

Today, Her Royal Highness, Fourth Warden of The Fishmongers’ Company, paid a private visit to Drapers’ Hall where she met members of the @FishmongersCo staff and Court members, including those affected by the attack.

The Princess Royal paid respects to the victims of Friday’s London Bridge terror attack yesterday by signing the @cityoflondon Book of Condolence at @GuildhallArt. If you’d like to sign the book of condolence visit: http://bit.ly/2RlHMeC pic.twitter.com/cjUAh3un6f

Mr Said Rustamov, Ambassador from the Republic of Uzbekistan was also received by The Queen. Mrs Rustamova was also received by Her Majesty. Find out more about Audiences at Buckingham Palace here: https://www.royal.uk/audiences pic.twitter.com/wkm9By0p7M

It is tradition for all new Ambassadors and High Commissioners to be presented to The Queen, as they begin their posts in The UK. Today Her Majesty received Dr Morie Komba Manyeh, High Commissioner for Sierra Leone at Buckingham Palace. Mrs Manyeh was also present.pic.twitter.com/P0EidK8uct

The Duchess of Cambridge speaks to parents about the services offered by @family_action to tackle difficult issues facing families. These include perinatal mental health services, counselling and therapeutic support and the mentoring of children, young people and adults.pic.twitter.com/hrD3wOi2DK

The Duchess, with families and children supported by @family_action, step into the 'Elves Enchanted Forest’ @Peterleyfarm to make Christmas decorations, prepare food for the reindeers and post letters to Father Christmas .pic.twitter.com/I9bqHKUVRA

The Duchess of Cambridge joins children supported by @family_action as they pick Christmas trees @Peterleyfarm. HRH has become Royal Patron of @family_action https://bit.ly/2LmbfRU pic.twitter.com/wf6GBIylob

The Duke of Cambridge learnt more about the Royal Navy of Oman’s responsibilities monitoring maritime traffic passing through the Strait of Hormuz. Oman and Kuwait are key partners for the UK, and The Duke met military personnel who are sharing expertise to improve security.pic.twitter.com/brRTLw7r68

In Kuwait and Oman, The Duke of Cambridge has spent time understanding the important security history of the region, and the UK’s current links with both countries from a defence perspective. In Kuwait, HRH joined Kuwaiti and UK troops undertaking a Desert Warrior Exercise.pic.twitter.com/QkLYQUGvY7

Since 2013 the prize has been awarded on alternate years and has become the world’s most prestigious engineering accolade. It celebrates ground breaking innovations in engineering and it is hoped to inspire the next generation of engineers.pic.twitter.com/o13bieyyVC
The technology uses satellites and their signals to determine the receiver’s location. It was first developed in the 1970s. Today an estimated four billion people use GPS.pic.twitter.com/n4llj4lz1W

GPS has revolutionised modern society. It has enabled anyone with a smartphone to pinpoint their exact location on earth at any time. It is used in a range of applications including aviation safety, banking, shipping, logistics and travel directions.pic.twitter.com/Tv5SW6OPlD

Dr Bradford Parkinson, Professor James Spilker, Jr, Hugo FrueHauf, and Richard Schwartz were all awarded the 2019 prize. Sadly Professor James Spilker passed away in September. His wife Anna received his award today.pic.twitter.com/sZxtLsyXpN

Yesterday The Prince of Wales, on behalf of Her Majesty The Queen, presented The Queen Elizabeth Prize for Engineering to a team of scientists whose work and development on the Global Positioning System (GPS) is now invaluable to so many people around the world.pic.twitter.com/HPEJgmeynR
Listen to The Duke of Edinburgh's 2016 interview on @BBCr4today programme here: https://bit.ly/363Pmyu and read his article in full for @newscientist here:https://bit.ly/2PaKaCq

In a 2015 article for @NewScientist, he wrote of the huge contribution engineers make to our everyday lives: ‘It is one of the few ways in which human talent can be given the chance to improve, and frequently to transform, the comfort and prosperity of the human community.’pic.twitter.com/liq3fGPFT4

The Prince’s father, The Duke of Edinburgh, has been a great advocate for engineers. In a @BBCr4Today interview in 2016, he spoke of the positive impact of engineers on the world around us, saying: ‘Everything that wasn't invented by God was invented by an engineer.’pic.twitter.com/vPRWyfmMhX

The Princess Royal, The Duchess of Cambridge and The Duke and Duchess of Gloucester meet NATO leaders, members of delegations and @NATO staff in the Picture Gallery.pic.twitter.com/JfLmO8Wk56 – at Buckingham Palace

An official photograph of Her Majesty The Queen, The Prince of Wales, NATO Secretary General and Heads of State and Government from countries who form the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation.pic.twitter.com/DMQp3wGQ6m – at Buckingham Palace
Her Majesty speaks to @NATO leaders in the Green Drawing Room. Heads of State and Government are in London to attend the NATO Leaders' Meeting 2019.pic.twitter.com/uWLuZPmjBP

The Queen, with The Prince of Wales and The Duchess of Cornwall, welcome Heads of State and Government of @NATO countries, and their spouses or partners, to Buckingham Palace.pic.twitter.com/ma0S5tPlzv

The @NATO alliance is now formed of 29 countries, with North Macedonia in the process of becoming the 30th member state. Heads of State & Government arrive at the Grand Entrance of Buckingham Palace ahead of the reception and are greeted by the Deputy Master of the Household.pic.twitter.com/hpnLu8ijmh

More recently, in 2015, The Queen visited the HQ of @NATO's Allied Rapid Reaction Corps at Imjin Barracks. @NATO exists to protect the people and territory of its members, and is founded on the principle of collective defence.pic.twitter.com/29wqmtwME0

In 1980 The Queen and The Duke of Edinburgh visited the @NATO HQ in Belgium and attended a meeting of the North Atlantic Council. Watch footage from the visit, courtesy of @NATO archives.pic.twitter.com/9VoXLZcEVX

Watch archive footage of The Queen & The Duke of Edinburgh visiting the Commander of @NATO's Allied Command Operations, General Norstad, in 1957. The North Atlantic Treaty - or Washington Treaty - forms the basis of NATO. It was signed on 4 April 1949 by 12 founding members.pic.twitter.com/LvhlEXrrN3
Her Majesty The Queen will host a reception for @NATO leaders at Buckingham Palace this evening, to mark 70 years of the Alliance.pic.twitter.com/GjHBICHcBv

For the latest updates on #RoyalVisitKuwait and #RoyalVisitOman , follow @KensingtonRoyal. We’ll also be posting a round-up of each day’s events on the Royal Family website: https://bit.ly/2Rew855 pic.twitter.com/W7t9Frfo8V
In 2012 The Queen hosted the Emir of Kuwait during His Highness’s State Visit to the UK, holding a State Banquet in his honour at Windsor Castle. #RoyalVisitKuwaitpic.twitter.com/VMsRzMnpOT
In 1993, The Prince of Wales was presented with The Order of Mubarak the Great, which is given as a sign of friendship between Kuwait and the recipient.pic.twitter.com/a8e3ynj3tR

Today, The Duke of Cambridge follows in the footsteps of his grandmother The Queen and his father The Prince of Wales who have both been welcomed to Kuwait by the Emir. https://twitter.com/KensingtonRoyal/status/1201451033366581248 …pic.twitter.com/BecwdAQE6T
Royal visits overseas help build and reinforce diplomatic relationships with foreign countries.https://twitter.com/KensingtonRoyal/status/1201420190308806658 …

The Duke of Cambridge is currently in Kuwait where his visit will highlight the country’s strong links with the UK in in areas including the environment, education and defence.https://twitter.com/KensingtonRoyal/status/1201418235998064640 …
A message from Her Majesty The Queen following the attack at London Bridge yesterday.https://bit.ly/2OxqklE
‘I express my enduring thanks to the police and emergency services, as well as the brave individuals who put their own lives at risk to selflessly help and protect others.’ - Elizabeth R (2/2)

‘Prince Philip and I have been saddened to hear of the terror attacks at London Bridge. We send our thoughts, prayers and deepest sympathies to all those who have lost loved ones and who have been affected by yesterday’s terrible violence.’ (1/2)

The Countess was reunited with some of the women she had first met in Jan '19 at the International Women's Day reception. It was here that HRH announced that she would champion for women’s full and meaningful participation in peace processes. in full: https://bit.ly/37SwyEv pic.twitter.com/Gejjayqmud

Through peer-to-peer mentoring, and training & network development workshops, the WMC network supports experienced mediators as they advocate for: increased recognition of women mediators. participation in peace processes regionally and internationally.pic.twitter.com/fMhxBeY00W

"Women Mediators across the Commonwealth" network, coordinated by @CRbuildpeace, brings together nearly 50 women, from peace negotiators at a government level to women mediating at a grassroots level, working in their communities.pic.twitter.com/vZR3xlbzuT

Women mediators and peacebuilders welcomed The Countess of Wessex to their discussions earlier this week. HRH joined the "Women Mediators across the Commonwealth" network, as part of her ongoing work in the #WomenPeaceSecurity arena.pic.twitter.com/ARXjBVzAyH

The Duke of Gloucester, Patron of @japansocietylon, plants the first of 6,500 Sakura cherry trees, gifted to the UK by Japan @JapanUKSakura will see the planting of the trees across the UK’s parks, gardens and schools to celebrate Japan’s relationship with the UK pic.twitter.com/nj3pb6aTAe
watch as The Countess learns about the @FootstepsF spider physio therapy equipment.pic.twitter.com/sSYoISlIvz

HRH met 14 year old Melissa, who uses the specialist ‘spider’ physio therapy equipment. Melissa spoke to The Countess about her weekly sessions to help her movement after a spinal injury.pic.twitter.com/eSQfY2zPQR

The Countess of Wessex is visiting Footsteps Foundation. @FootstepsF supports children with cerebral palsy and other neurological disorders. The charity provides children with specialist physiotherapist care. Currently 8 physiotherapists treat around 180 children per year.pic.twitter.com/2T9rbmijEo

As Patron of the Association of Show and Agricultural Organisations, HRH is heavily involved with agriculture and land. At @earth_trust , The Countess learns more about the charity’s work in tackling local environmental challenges.pic.twitter.com/SHTW9viAii

The Countess officially opens the charity’s newly-restored Anglo Saxon building - the “House of Wessex”, which will be used as an educational facility.pic.twitter.com/gdJDMcJlcA – at Sylva Foundation Wood Centre

Inside the Wood Centre workshop The Countess talks with furniture design makers Andrew and Daisy, who are supported by the charity. The pair set up their own business ‘Lula James’ in September, making bespoke wooden furniture and small crafts.pic.twitter.com/tnkBRZgRNu – at Sylva Foundation Wood Centre

Today The Countess of Wessex is visiting Oxfordshire. HRH is at the @SylvaFoundation, an environmental charity that supports Britain’s trees and woodlands - helping to care for 90,000 hectares across the UK pic.twitter.com/w27DOwXfCX – at Sylva Foundation Wood Centre

Malcolm East was also presented with his MBE today. Malcolm has supported the Welsh Community of Llandrindod Wells with extensive first aid training. He also set up the Community First Responder Scheme. Isolated rural areas across Wales are benefitting from more first aid access.pic.twitter.com/HhQvyaVcOL – at Buckingham Palace

William Reid received his MBE today. William is an Ambassador for @Soldierscharity. He has raised over £100,000 for military veterans. After being injured by an IED in Afghanistan and becoming a triple amputee, William supports others with life threatening injuries.pic.twitter.com/Vcu9hgIITe – at Buckingham Palace

King George V’s reign saw the first commemorative stamps in 1924, since then special stamps have been used to mark many national events and anniversaries. King George VI and Queen Elizabeth’s Silver Wedding Anniversary in 1948.pic.twitter.com/8lZyqpipcc

The world’s first stamp, the Penny Black, featured an effigy of the head of Queen Victoria, as engraved by William Wyon (official chief engraver at the Royal Mint) to mark her Coronation in 1838.pic.twitter.com/ZTSarA57u5

Arnold Machin’s effigy of The Queen, which has featured on UK stamps since 1967, is widely considered to be one of the most reproduced and iconic images in the world. It has been reprinted an estimated 220 billion times, in more than 130 different colours.pic.twitter.com/v2EHFGQq5N

These photographs taken by Dorothy Wilding, of Her Majesty in 1952, were used as the basis of The Queen’s image on postage stamps from 1953 until 1971. In two sittings, photographer Wilding took 59 images of The Queen. @RCTpic.twitter.com/9sySYyA5SF

Queen Maud was the first Queen of modern Norway and the granddaughter of Queen Victoria. She married Prince Carl of Denmark in 1896 & Carl was elected King of Norway in 1905. Maud & Carl were given Appleton House on the Sandringham Estate as a wedding gift from Maud's parents.

The 1998-99 conflict in Kosovo saw rape used as a systematic weapon of war, devastating the lives of thousands of women, men & children. Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is a potentially avoidable eye condition that affects premature babies. The oxygen given to babies in the incubator to survive can damage their immature retinal blood vessels. Without detection and treatment it can cause irreversible blindness.pic.twitter.com/izpnG0ep9d

HRH also added that in 2014, when The Queen Elizabeth Diamond Jubilee Trust – of which she is a Vice-Patron – began work in Malawi, 8 million people were at risk of losing their sight to trachoma. Now there are none. Read the full letter here -http://bit.ly/2O3J3DH

The Countess also said that it's thanks to Malawi’s Ministry of Health, organisations working closely together within the International Coalition for Trachoma Control & the communities themselves that the people of Malawi are no longer at risk of going blind from trachoma.pic.twitter.com/wykmjtbFU8
"But now trachoma is preventable and treatable. With leadership and a concerted effort over several years, it can be eliminated," The Countess added.pic.twitter.com/Ykz7tVz7LO

"For millennia, trachoma has blighted the lives of millions. Slowly and painfully, people lose their sight. They become unable to leave their homes, go to work and provide for their families," The Countess said. @qejubileetrust #CommonwealthDaypic.twitter.com/URwNxmfPH5

This #CommonwealthDay The Countess of Wessex has written a letter to the people of Malawi - congratulating them on removing the risk of trachoma. "I then followed the gun carriage on foot to Westminster Abbey where the burial took place, the grave was filled in with soil brought from France. The Service was beautiful & conducted by the Dean… everything was most beautifully arranged & carried out…"pic.twitter.com/Se8m7CFu66
In his diary, The King reflects on this day: “At 11.0. I unveiled the Cenotaph & then followed two minutes silence throughout the whole Empire. The whole ceremony was most moving & impressive.”

Major Edward Basil Blogg was appointed Clerk in the Lord Chamberlain's Office in 1907. During the war he served in the Royal Engineers, having previously been part of their Territorial Force. He was killed in action on 16 March 1916.

Private William Robertson was appointed Stoker of the Heating apparatus at Balmoral Castle in 1907. In September 1914 he enlisted, serving in the Gordon Highlanders, and saw action during many of the large scale battles on the Western Front.

Among those who served was Ursula Mary Lawley, a Maid of Honour to Queen Mary. In November 1914 she volunteered as a Serving Sister in the Order of St John, working in military hospitals in France. She then returned to her pre-war role, relinquishing it in 1927.pic.twitter.com/AUfOmam64q

Acting as a written memorial to those who served, the booklet documents that 143 were killed, 153 were wounded, 225 saw active service & survived the war, & 174 served at home, including as Special Constables, recruiting & training, at supply depots and guarding the coastline.pic.twitter.com/2Y3ek6N3qn

During the First World War, 694 men & 1 woman from the Royal Household & Private Estates enlisted for military service. After the War, the ‘War Service Roll of the Members of The Royal Household and Estates of the King and the Queen’ was published. #Armistice100pic.twitter.com/MyikOoLHgA

The Royal Family set aside an area of Frogmore Gardens for a potato plot. Queen Mary records in her diary on 24 April 1917: "We again went to Frogmore to finish planting our potato plot & worked from 3 to 5 – got very hot & tired". Read more: https://www.royal.uk/first-world-war-royal-archives …pic.twitter.com/43V4dFJd0a

Towards the end of 1916, after a series of bad harvests, German blockades and the loss of vital shipping, the British Government encouraged people to grow their own vegetables.pic.twitter.com/PDYHauQxQT

On 3 March 1915, Brig-Gen. Harry Watson writes to the King's Private Secretary: "four big bundles of warm socks have lately arrived for my brigade…and to say how deeply indebted we all are to Her Majesty for the…kind thought of sending them. They are of infinite value to us"

During the First World War, Queen Mary's Needlework Guild organised gifts to be sent to soldiers and sailors abroad. In charge of proceedings, Queen Mary requested garments and parcels to be sent to Friary Court, St. James’s Palace for distribution to the frontline.

1917, St James' Palace, during a presentation to Queen Mary from the British and Canadian Needlework Guild of gifts to be sent overseas to military personnel by its President, Princess Beatrice [The Queen's aunt-in-law]. On the Queen's left is her daughter Princess Mary.pic.twitter.com/owKJSOjNYb

"…The entertainment consisted of various artistes, acrobats, conjurors etc., an excellent choir singing songs of which the men knew the choruses, & sang them most 'heartily'. How you would have liked being present, it was all so informal, friendly and nice."

On 24 March 1916, Queen Mary writes to her aunt, Princess Augusta of Cambridge, describing these parties: "they had tea first in the Coach Houses, members of our family presiding at each table & being helped by the ladies & gentlemen of our household, & various friends of ours…"pic.twitter.com/69Qud6yc24

The Royal Family hosted entertainments for wounded soldiers and sailors in the Riding School at Buckingham Palace during #WWI. Over three days in March 1916 more than 2000 men were able to attend these events.pic.twitter.com/GfxFKV3nDH

18 September 1917: The Queen and Princess Mary visited Coventry "to see Munition girls at work. Arrived 11.20 met by the Mayor and Mayoress & went to White Poppe's works which meant we went over & saw Machine Shop, Ambulance Room, Recreation hall etc."pic.twitter.com/w75fl5F2n7
16 May 1917: Queen Mary visits the Manchester Royal Infirmary.pic.twitter.com/me72VMOFLu

During the course of the First World War, George V & Queen Mary toured hundreds of factories, shipyards & hospitals across Britain. The King and Queen visit Sopwith Aviation works on 19 April 1917. #Armistice100pic.twitter.com/hZrUzxc44l

In July 1917 Queen Mary accompanied King George V on his visit to the frontline. Their Majesties arrived in France on 3 July, undertaking an extensive 12 day tour, meeting the troops. This programme outlines the first two days of Their Majesties visit.pic.twitter.com/fzsp3xQdmR

On the last day of his visit, The King sent this message, via a Special Order of the Day; “I cannot share in your trials, dangers and successes, but I can assure you of the proud confidence and gratitude of myself and of your fellow countrymen.”pic.twitter.com/UckoaGvv1f

A few days later on 27 October, Maurice, aged just 23, was killed while ‘leading his company in an attack when he was struck by a shrapnel bullet’. Prince Maurice is buried at Ypres Town @CWGC & there is a memorial to him at the Royal Burial Ground at Frogmore.pic.twitter.com/RopNdZwfeQ
18 October 1914: Prince Maurice writes to his mother informing her that he was safe at Hazebrouck and how “it was heavenly spending last night peacefully in bed”.pic.twitter.com/1wafS2XYmK

Alexander’s brother, Prince Maurice also served & was part of the BEF who arrived in France in August 1914. In this letter to his mother, dated 16 September 1914, Maurice refers to the wounding of his brother & the heavy losses of his own Company.pic.twitter.com/RBLg3Iw5R3

“Lots of us were shot down getting back, and I was so exhausted that I finally fell. I knew I could run no further, so crawled for over 300 yards on my stomach, whilst the ground round me was simply riddled with bullets. I confess I thought it was the end.”pic.twitter.com/TRotTadKLm
16 September 1914: Alexander, who was a Lieutenant in the Grenadier Guards, writes again to his mother during “a lull in the 3rd day of a great battle which…has been a terrible experience”

Two of Queen Victoria’s grandchildren served in #WWI, including Prince Alexander of Battenberg. In this letter from 29 August 1914 to his mother, Princess Beatrice, he describes his experience: “you can hardly imagine anything more horrible”. #Armistice100pic.twitter.com/x1ZsZ7jmSC

Find out more about Prince Albert’s role in #WWI: https://www.royal.uk/first-world-war-royal-archives … #Armistice100

In March 1918, in a letter to Queen Mary, he describes his first flight:”It was a curious sensation & one which takes a lot of getting used to. I did enjoy it on the whole, but I don't think I should like flying as a pastime. I would much sooner be on the ground! It feels safer!”pic.twitter.com/jGpiXGG5I4
In January 1918, Albert was transferred to the Royal Naval Air Service & learnt to fly at Cranwell – becoming the first member of The Royal Family to hold a pilot’s license.

Certificate address to Prince Albert informing him that he had been mentioned in dispatches for his role in the Battle of Jutland, which had appeared in the London Gazette on 15 September 1916.pic.twitter.com/vmLNDTkOKD

“At the commencement I was sitting on the top of A turret and had a very good view of the proceedings. I was up there during a lull, when a German ship started firing at us.” Prince Albert is photographed aboard HMS Collingwood in 1914.pic.twitter.com/UZ5kO6T5qW

An account of the Battle of Jutland by Prince Albert – who remains the only British Sovereign to have seen action in battle since King William IV. “We went to ‘Action Stations’ at 4.30 p.m. and saw the Battle Cruisers in action ahead of us on the starboard bow”pic.twitter.com/usVQallyG7

“A battle is now going on in Belgium between the Germans against the French & Belgians, probably a million men are engaged on each side, it is too awful to contemplate." The King also affectionately tells The Prince that "You can be sure that you are constantly in my thoughts".

In September 1913 Prince Albert (the future George VI) was commissioned as a Midshipman on board HMS Collingwood, on which he still serving at the outbreak of WWI. In this letter from 13 August 1914, Albert’s father, George V, keeps his son updated on events: #Armistice100pic.twitter.com/Q7RC5UrIQL

Their Royal Highness visited the cultural corner of Accra meeting young people and local artists. The Prince of Wales also met the Okyenhene. Okyenhene is the title of the King of Akyem Abuakwa, an ancient kingdom in the Eastern Region of Ghana. #RoyalVisitGhana pic.twitter.com/uhuT4wjy0v
The Queen has previously stayed in the Castle, in this room, on a state visit in 1961. #RoyalVisitGhana pic.twitter.com/ev6n59iCd0

Today The Prince of Wales visited Osu Castle which previously was a residence of President Kwame Nkrumah. However the principal occupation before slavery was abolished was trading of human beings. It is estimated that six million people were traded as slaves from West Africa.pic.twitter.com/A32VktMIcj

“As a General at the front is reported to have said, & as I have always maintained, “That is a damned good boy!” & he has already become unanimously popular with the Army out here.” Find out more about Edward, Prince of Wales’ role in #WWI:https://www.royal.uk/first-world-war-royal-archives …

This letter, from December 1914, was forwarded to George V’s Private Secretary & reflects the high esteem HRH was regarded by the soldiers at the Front: “Today who should I come upon, tramping along on front in the very worst of it (i.e. the “liquid mud”) but the Prince of Wales”pic.twitter.com/gT7PxgQjji

The Prince surveyed the trenches used in the defensive line of St Venant-St Omer-Eperlecques in February 1915 – he reconnoitred the whole length of the 30km of trenches on foot over the course of four and a half days.pic.twitter.com/AQrkbLRzcM

Arriving at GHQ on 16 November 1914, The Prince spent time in various departments in order to gain an insight into their respective activities. This map of the French lines, drawn by HRH in January 1915, was part of his time working for Field Marshal Sir John French.pic.twitter.com/63tLDS6D8s

The Prince’s anxiety to go to France led him to appeal to Lord Kitchener, & eventually it was decided that he could be posted to the General Headquarters of Field-Marshal Sir John French, Commander-in-Chief of the BEF, in France.

In mid-August 1914, The Prince wrote to his mother, Queen Mary, describing his experience at Warley Barracks: “The officers are all very nice & helpful & I already feel quite at home here, as they treat me just as one of themselves & there is no formality.”pic.twitter.com/bY3VsXgiS4

After the outbreak of War, Edward, Prince of Wales was desperate to serve, but as heir to the throne, it was impossible to allow him to fight in France. However, The Prince was allowed to join the 1st Battalion of the Grenadier Guards on 11 August 1914. #Armistice100pic.twitter.com/ygsKqiLgLT

Find out more about how The Royal Family supported the troops during Christmas 1914: https://www.royal.uk/first-world-war-royal-archives … #Armistice100

In 1914, George V and Queen Mary sent out Christmas cards to every member of the British Armed Forces. 3 versions were produced, one for the Army, one of the Navy & one for the sick and wounded, which had a special message with good wishes for their recovery.pic.twitter.com/R8Z67e564W

Rawlinson also describes how "Xmas time has brought a certain feeling of 'rapprochement' between the garrisons of the trenches & yesterday there was a sort of mutual armistice to bury the dead and get in the wounded that were lying out between the two lines of trenches.”

In this letter, dated 26 December 1914, Major General Sir Henry Rawlinson writes to Clive Wigram, Private Secretary to King George V, asking him to thank Princess Mary for the Gift Box, "and say how much we all value her kind gift of tobacco & cigarettes".pic.twitter.com/MkhnVfpLKS

The present was an embossed brass box, which bore a profile of Princess Mary with the initial ‘M’ on either side, within a decorative border containing the names of the Allies at the beginning of the War and the words ‘Christmas 1914’. Inside were gifts eg. tobacco, sweets etc.

14 October 1914: Princess Mary, daughter of King George V & Queen Mary, inaugurates the '‘Princess Mary’s Sailors’ and Soldiers’ Christmas Fund'’ so that a Christmas gift could be sent to all at the Front – approximately 2.5 million gifts were distributed. #Armistice100pic.twitter.com/v89DFVi6pv

“An enormous crowd collected outside the Palace… & it was a never to be forgotten sight when May & I with David went on to the balcony, the cheering was terrific. Please God it may be soon over & that he will protect dear Bertie's life”

It will take 6 months to move all the @RCT artworks and furniture from The East Wing to @BrightonMuseums Royal Pavilion – returning them to the original location they were intended for under King George IV. #ReservicingBPpic.twitter.com/xj15rHdYmU
The Reservicing programme will improve visitor access and make the Palace more energy efficient. Find out more here: https://www.royal.uk/decant-east-wing-buckingham-palace … #ReservicingBP

Designed by Edward Blore in the 1840s, the East Wing of Buckingham Palace was built for Queen Victoria to provide more entertaining and living space for her expanding family. Now it’s used by The Royal Family on many national occasions, including annually at Trooping the Colour.pic.twitter.com/PjCQ63wWxD

This will ensure priceless paintings, porcelain and furniture will be protected, whilst infrastructure such as electrics and pipework are replaced, and improvements to accessibility are made throughout the Wing. #ReservicingBPpic.twitter.com/80YkmxhvfE

Many of the artworks will be moved to other locations around the Palace, but around 150 items will go on public display at @BrightonMuseums Royal Pavilion (where The Duke and Duchess of Sussex visited earlier this week!) #ReservicingBPpic.twitter.com/slApaf2gTx

Around 3,000 fine artworks from @RCT are being removed from Buckingham Palace’s East Wing to allow essential reservicing works to take place in Spring 2019. Some items will now go on display at @BrightonMuseums Royal Pavilion for members of the public to see. #ReservicingBPpic.twitter.com/t4Pl6EnT4I

28 August 1918, Gen. Rawlinson sends an account of the battle to Clive Wigram. These pages show the role of the RAF & Tank Regiments: "It has shown the enemy that his…offensive has failed to reduce our moral, and the campaign of 1918 is likely to finish in favour of the Allies"pic.twitter.com/RRPD251VAC
"The troops especially Canadians and Australians fought magnificently. I have never seen any troops in so big a state of fighting spirit and efficiency."

From the Royal Archives: 18 August 1918, General Henry Rawlinson, Commander of IVth Army, writes to Clive Wigram, George V's Assistant Private Secretary, about the Battle: "It was a great battle and everything went off exactly according to programme." #Amiens100pic.twitter.com/EqKIrqU2EF

Starting on the 8 August 1918, the Battle of Amiens marked a turning point in WWI – the allied forces, made up of British, Australian, Canadian, French & US Soldiers advanced over 7 miles on 1st day of the battle – as shown in this map from the Royal Archives. #Amiens100pic.twitter.com/HJRwaOTng0

The Queen's father, George VI, was The Duke of York until the abdication of his brother, Edward VIII, in 1936 and he became King.pic.twitter.com/8LglmlH9m6

The next Duke of York wasn't created until 1892, when Prince George - future George V & second son of Edward VII – was given the Dukedom by his grandmother, Queen Victoria. This photograph shows Prince George, Duke of York, with his wife Mary & Queen Victoria in 1893.pic.twitter.com/uVsob49pbk
Charles I and his son James II (James VII of Scotland) were both the second sons of Monarchs and The Duke of York before becoming King.pic.twitter.com/FiDuI8ZyLB

#DYK that Henry VIII was also The Duke of York? His elder brother Prince Arthur, Prince of Wales was heir to the throne, but after his death in 1502 Henry, Duke of York became the Prince of Wales and eventually King in 1509.pic.twitter.com/YGknyxKDwU

Historically The Duke of York has been the second son of the Monarch. This started in 1474 with Prince Richard - one of the 'Princes in the Tower'. Richard & his brother Edward V were taken to the Tower of London in 1483 by their uncle Richard III & never seen again.pic.twitter.com/MeACiIVcc7

The White Rose was first associated with Yorkshire in 1385 when the 4th surviving son of Edward III, Edmund Langley, became the first Duke of York. The Duke, whose descendants would go onto take part in the Wars of the Roses, features heavily in Shakespeare's 'Richard II'.pic.twitter.com/ypKUkuLXvW

"Since it has pleased Providence to place me in this station, I shall do my utmost to fulfil my duty towards my country." You explore Queen Victoria's journals here: http://www.queenvictoriasjournals.org/

"I got out of bed and went into my sitting-room (only in my dressing-gown), and alone, and saw them. Lord Conyngham then acquainted me that my poor Uncle, the King, was no more, and he had expired at 12 minutes p.12 this morning, and consequently that I am Queen."

#OTD in 1837 Queen Victoria acceded the Throne following the death of her uncle, King William IV. She describes the day in her journals: "I was awoke at 6 o'clock by Mamma, who told me that the Archbishop of Canterbury and Lord Conyngham were here and wished to see me."pic.twitter.com/QP0GgBxmhD

"We came home at 2. The courtyard & streets were crammed when we went to the Ball, & the anxiety of the people to see poor stupid me, was very great. I must say I am quite touched & proud, which I always have been, of my Country…"

"At ½ p. 10 we went to a Ball at St. James's…The King, though much better, was unable to be there, as was the Queen, so, strange to say, Aunt Augusta did the honours, I danced a good deal, & enjoyed myself very much."

"I shall from this day take the firm resolution to study with renewed assiduity & always to keep my attention well fixed on whatever I am about, & to strive every day to become more fit for what, if Heaven wills it, I am some day to be!..."

The George Cross was instituted by King George VI on 24 September 1940, during the height of the blitz. The George Cross is granted in recognition of "acts of the greatest heroism or of the most conspicuous courage in circumstances of extreme danger".pic.twitter.com/Udeadghb76

The Victoria Cross was instituted by Queen Victoria in 29 January 1856. It is awarded "for most conspicuous bravery or some daring pre-eminent act of valour or self-sacrifice or extreme devotion to duty in the presence of the enemy".pic.twitter.com/uPFgrweGTE
Her Majesty has long connection with the Association & has been Patron since 1957, following its foundation during the Victoria Cross Centenary Celebrations on 26 June 1956.pic.twitter.com/zrUW5cRWZV
